name: Hyperautomation
description: The combination of RPA, ML, and AI to automate increasingly complex business processes end-to-end, not just individual tasks.
accuracyNote: Gartner described RPA + traditional ML automating business processes. RPA grew but hit limits quickly. The real automation breakthrough came via LLM-based agents in 2024-2025 — a completely different technology stack than the RPA + ML pipeline Gartner envisioned. The 'hyperautomation' that's actually working looks nothing like the 2020 description.

name: Multiexperience
description: Users would interact through multisensory and multimodal experiences spanning wearables, AR/VR, conversational interfaces, and traditional screens.
accuracyNote: Predicted multisensory experiences spanning wearables, AR/VR, and conversational interfaces. Wearable and AR/VR interaction remained niche. Conversational AI succeeded, but via LLMs — an entirely different technology than the NLP chatbots Gartner described. The term 'multiexperience' itself never caught on.

name: Democratization of Technology
description: No-code/low-code platforms, AI tools, and citizen development would provide access to technical or business expertise without extensive training.
accuracyNote: No-code/low-code platforms grew but remain niche for serious applications. The real democratization happened via LLMs (ChatGPT making code/analysis accessible), which wasn't what Gartner described. Credit for the theme, not the mechanism.

name: Human Augmentation
description: Technology would augment human cognitive and physical capabilities through wearables, AI assistants, and even implants.
accuracyNote: Predicted wearables, AI assistants, and physical implants augmenting humans. Physical augmentation (exoskeletons, Neuralink) remains experimental. Cognitive augmentation happened via LLM assistants, but that's a completely different mechanism than the 'embedded AI in wearables and implants' vision. The prediction described hardware-centric augmentation; reality was software-centric.

name: Transparency and Traceability
description: Growing demands for ethical AI, data privacy, and regulatory compliance would require organizations to be transparent about how they use data and AI.
accuracyNote: EU AI Act and GDPR enforcement are real, but 'growing demands for ethical AI and data privacy would require transparency' was a fairly obvious prediction many people were making by 2020. Directionally correct but not precise about HOW regulation would work.

name: The Empowered Edge
description: Edge computing would become increasingly sophisticated, with more powerful edge devices and edge AI enabling real-time processing at the point of need.
accuracyNote: Edge AI and 5G edge exist but haven't been transformative for most organizations. The prediction oversold edge computing's impact — it remains a useful niche, not the revolution described.

name: Distributed Cloud
description: Public cloud services would be distributed to different physical locations while governance, operations, and evolution remain the responsibility of the public cloud provider.
accuracyNote: AWS Outposts and Azure Arc exist but haven't been widely adopted. Most enterprises use standard multi-region cloud, not 'distributed cloud' with services at arbitrary physical locations. Adoption is more limited than the prediction implied.

name: Autonomous Things
description: Drones, robots, and autonomous vehicles would move from controlled to more open environments, collaborating with each other and humans.
accuracyNote: Still overly optimistic — warehouse robots succeeded but open-environment autonomy remains limited. Autonomous vehicles still aren't mainstream by 2026.

name: Practical Blockchain
description: Blockchain would mature past the hype to deliver practical value in supply chain verification, identity management, and financial services.
accuracyNote: Limited — some supply chain use cases emerged, but 'practical blockchain' remained elusive for most enterprises. The crypto crash of 2022 dampened enterprise enthusiasm.

name: AI Security
description: AI would be used to enhance security operations, while also creating new attack vectors that organizations would need to defend against.
accuracyNote: 'AI would enhance security and create new attack vectors' is so obvious for any dual-use technology that it barely counts as a bold prediction. Both sides materialized, but the specifics (deepfakes, prompt injection) weren't called out.
